li.a: Información sobre el coronavirus en español
Akhbaarta cudurka Koroonaha oo ku qoran afka Somaliga
Lus qhia txog tus kabmob coronavirus hais ua lus Hmoob

p.span: The City is open to accepting donations from private individuals or entities for the Gap Funds for Housing and the Forgivable No-Interest Loans for Small Business Program. Donors could direct said donations to be expended consistent with the Program guidelines, but would not have any additional control over how the donation is allocated. Please contact us if you are interested in donating.

hr.p: To combat COVID-19, leaders must act quickly but our actions must also be informed by the best obtainable data. That’s how the City of Minneapolis has approached assembling its new set of gap funds to support renters, families and businesses.

The state legislature authorized over $300 million and the federal government advanced a record-setting $2 trillion package to support residents and businesses impacted by the pandemic. At the local level, we’re taking steps to make sure that our new programs complement, not duplicate, the work made possible by the new state and federal funding.
Mayor Frey in partnership with the City Council and City leadership are dedicating more than $5 million for Minneapolis residents and businesses hit hardest by this crisis
Español | Soomaali | Hmoob | Oromo

h3.span: Applications are no longer being accepted. Applicants will be contacted soon regarding the status of their request.

hr.p: Information that applicants will need to have available to apply:

ul.li: Annual household gross income (before taxes) for May 2019 through April 2020
Current monthly household gross income
Amount of household income lost due to COVID-19 (EHA program)
Amount of assistance needed to solve household’s current housing emergency
Whether one or more children in the household are currently enrolled in a Minneapolis Public School elementary school. If yes, the name of the school (SHSS program).

p.strong: Please note: Immigration or documentation status does not affect eligibility.

p.br: EHA assistance eligible applicants will be assigned a random application number to establish a list order and will be referred to community partner organizations based on that list order. Community partner organizations will contact applicants and request documentation to verify income and need. If documentation is not available, applicants may self-certify income and income loss.

p.strong: Stable Homes Stable Schools (SHSS) Emergency Expansion:
p.br: SHSS eligible applicants will be referred to the Minneapolis Public Housing Authority (MPHA) to complete income, school attendance, and need verification. Additional documentation may be required on a case by case basis.

hr.p: For both programs, community partner organizations or MPHA will need to contact rental property owners for W9s and payment information, including owners of licensed rental property and individual homes where a room is rented to an applicant.
The City of Minneapolis has made up to $3 million available to Minneapolis renters during the COVID-19 crisis through the following programs.

p.br: The amount of assistance provided will depend on the individual needs of the household, taking into consideration other resources the household is eligible to receive. In most cases, the maximum amount of assistance will not exceed $1,500 per household, but providers will have the flexibility to provide up to $2,000 for larger households living in units with three or more bedrooms.

hr.p: Eligible expenses include:

ul.li: rent payments (late rent and rent due within 15 days)
utility payments
other housing stability related costs

p.strong: Stable Homes Stable Schools (SHSS) Emergency Expansion: $1 million
p.br: The amount of assistance provided will depend on the individual needs of the household, taking into consideration other resources the household is eligible to receive. In most cases, the maximum amount of assistance will not exceed $1,500 per household, but up to $2,000 will be available under extraordinary circumstances. Eligible expenses include:

ul.li: rent payments (including back rent)
utility payments
other housing stability related costs

hr.p: Payments will be made directly to the rental property owner and/or utility company.

The amount of assistance will depend on the individual needs of the household, taking into consideration other resources the household is eligible to receive. In most cases, the maximum amount of assistance will not exceed $1,500 per household, but providers will have the flexibility to provide up to $2,000 under extraordinary circumstances. Eligible expenses include rent payments, including rent in arrears and rent due within 15 days and utility payments. Payments will be made directly to the rental property owner and/or utility company.
Eligible families will:

ul.li: Reside in Minneapolis;
Have incomes of 30% AMI or below;
Have experienced a significant loss of income (from self-employed or any other source) due to the COVID-19 emergency;
Households are eligible irrespective of immigration or documentation status.

hr.p: The program is designed to serve households that are not served by other COVID-19 related federal or state assistance.
hr.h4: Income limits for Emergency Housing Assistance Program

td.strong: 2020 HUD Income Limits: 30% AMI by household size

h3.strong: Stable Homes Stable Schools Emergency Expansion

hr.p: To be eligible, families must meet all the following requirements:

ul.li: Have at least one child enrolled in one a Minneapolis Public School elementary school;

Have total gross annual income (before deducting taxes) of 50% or less of the area median income (AMI); however, households with gross annual household income at or below 30% AMI (see table under EHA assistance) will be prioritized for assistance.

hr.h4: Income limits for Stable Homes Stable Schools Program

td.strong: 2020 HUD Income Limits: 50% AMI by household size

ul.li: Applications must be submitted between 9:00 a.m. on Wednesday April 22 and noon on Monday April 27, 2020.
Applicants may only submit one application per household. City staff will assign the application to the appropriate program (EHA or SHSS program).
Applicant head of household must not be claimed as dependent on someone else's tax returns.

h3.span: Does an applicant have to provide a social security number, employee identification number, or ITIN?

hr.p: No.

h3.span: Do these funds have public charge implications for non-citizens?

hr.p: No. These are emergency relief funds, not classified as income maintenance.

br.span: Is this rental assistance taxable for applicants?

hr.p: No. The City’s payment is to the landlord, utility company or other third-party payee so there is no tax liability for the applicant.

h3.span: What if I have questions about the application?

hr.p: If you have questions about the application, please email [email protected].

h3.span: What will happen if there are more requests than available funds?

hr.p:
For Emergency Housing Assistance, assistance will be provided to eligible households in the list order established by randomly assigning a number to each applicant.
For Stable Homes Stable Schools, 30% AMI households will be prioritized.

h2.span: Minneapolis Gap Funds for Small Businesses

hr.p: There’s no corner of our city that COVID-19 will leave untouched. But we know that the economic burden of the pandemic will impact some communities more than others. Our targeted business relief programs reflect that reality.

With $2.2 million in City funds, the Minneapolis Gap Funds for Small Businesses include new Forgivable No-interest Loans for small businesses with 20 employees or less and people who are self-employed along with a revamped 2% Loan program, adjusted to 0%.

h3.span: Forgivable No-Interest Loans for Small Business

hr.p: The new Forgivable No-Interest Loans for Small Business will come in fixed amounts of $5,000 or $10,000, depending on need resulting from the COVID-19 emergency.

strong.span: Applications are no longer being accepted for these loans. Applicants will be contacted shortly regarding the status of their loan request.

hr.p: Soomaali | Hmoob | Español

strong.span: Who is eligible for this loan?

p.br: Businesses must be located in a designated area of Minneapolis, such as Cultural Districts, Promise Zone, Green Zone, or ACP50.

ul.li: Have 20 or fewer employees and/or $1 million or less in annual revenue;
Self-employed workers are eligible and
In good regulatory standing with the City

div.p: Please note: Immigration status does not impact eligibility.

strong.span: I have a mobile business and/or I work from my home, am I eligible?

div.p: Businesses or self-employed workers without a separate business address should enter their home address.
Businesses are not eligible if their primary services are any of the following:

ul.li: gambling
adult entertainment
registered lobbying
multi-level marketing
billboards
renting commercial or residential property

div.p: Nonprofits are also not eligible for this loan program.

strong.span: How much is the loan for?

div.p: A fixed amount of $5,000 or $10,000, depending on need resulting from the COVID-19 emergency.

strong.span: Can I apply for this in addition to State and Federal funding?

div.p: Yes. Businesses can apply for this loan in addition to any Federal or State funding, such as an SBA or DEED loan.
Applications are no longer being accepted for these loans. Applicants will be contacted shortly regarding the status of their loan request.
To apply, you will need to upload

ul.li: Documentation of business revenue from 2019 (or the business’ most recent fiscal year if different), e.g. tax return, financial statements, reports, or any such records that can verify business revenue.
Documentation of payroll and employee count, if any, as of March 1, 2020.

strong.span: How should sole proprietors, independent contractors, and the self-employed complete the “Employment” part of the application?

div.p: Self-employed people with no other employees should enter “0” for the number of W-2 full or part time employees. No payroll documentation is needed for businesses without employees. Documentation of business revenue is still required, which could include tax returns, financial statements, or other records of business income.

strong.span: Will the City look at my credit?

div.p: No. The City will not be looking at credit scores, and no collateral is required.

strong.span: What will happen if there are more loan requests than available funds?

div.p: If we receive loan requests in an amount that exceeds available funding we will use a lottery system with eligible applicants to determine final loan recipients.

span.strong: How will I be notified if I am selected to receive the loan?

div.p: Applicants will be notified of their status by email. Please note that no decisions will be made prior to the application deadline (April 20).

strong.span: What can I use the money for?

ul.li: Payroll and employee benefits
Rent or mortgage payments
Accounts payable and payments due to supply chain
And other critical working capital needs

strong.span: Will I need to make payments?

div.p: No. Loans have deferred payments for 12 months, and be 100% forgivable if the business continues to operate in Minneapolis in good regulatory standing.

strong.span: How will I know if my loan will be forgiven?

div.p: The loans are 100% forgivable after 12 months if the business continues to operate in Minneapolis and remains in good regulatory standing. Borrowers will submit quarterly reports to the City. Before the end of the twelve-month deferral period, borrowers will submit a final report. The City will use the information in that report, and any follow up information requested of the borrower, to determine whether the borrower meets the criteria for loan forgiveness.

strong.span: What if I have questions about the application?

div.p: If you have questions about the application, contact Minneapolis 311.

ul.li: For reasonable accommodations or alternative formats please contact the following resources.
People who are deaf and/or hard of hearing can use a relay service to call 311 at 612-673-3000. TTY users call 612-673-2157.
Para asistencia 612-673-2700
Rau kev pab 612-673-2800
Hadii aad Caawimaad u baahantahay 612-673-3500.

hr.p: We’re modifying the city’s existing 2% Participation Loan program for small businesses in two key ways:

ol.li: Expanding the eligible expenses to include working capital costs.

hr.p: These loans are available to businesses city-wide in amounts up to $50,000 or $75,000 depending on location to be matched by the lending partner.
These loans are originated and serviced by participating lenders and will have the following terms:

ul.li: Up to 10 years matched by the term of the lending partners’ loan;
Zero percent interest on the city’s portion of the loan;
Payments may be deferred for up to the first six (6) months matching the deferral terms of the Lending Partner;
Principal and interest amortized over term thereafter;

hr.p: Eligible borrowers will:

ul.li: Demonstrate a financial impact from the COVID-19 emergency;
Have 20 or fewer employees and/or $1 million or less in annual revenue;
Self-employed workers are eligible;

hr.p: We’ve also taken a closer look at city loans administered before the pandemic, and identified several ways we can help businesses do more.

For eligible and existing City-issued loans less than $200,000 to home buyers and businesses, the City is moving forward with six months of forbearance and deferred payments. The City will also seek forbearance on its commercial real estate loans greater than $200,000.
Finally, we’re doing more of what we know works.
We’re stepping up support from our Business Technical Assistance Program (B-TAP) with a $300,000 infusion, so more people can get city support navigating challenges brought by COVID-19.

We’re also investing $100,000 in the Twin Cities Hospitality Fund, a partnership fund with labor, civic, and business leaders to support low-wealth employees in the hospitality and service industry with micro-grants to cover basic needs.
Last updated Apr 27, 2020

div.p:
